reviewText:
The Music Machine is a pyschological horror walking simulator with a heavy emphasis exploration in the forms of exploring the game world and exploring the narration of the game.

In this game you play as a 13 year old girl named Hayley, who is currently posessed by the ghost of an older man named Quintin, who is trying to find a satisfactory way to kill Hayley for causing his untimely death. You start on an island where multiple people have been murdered recently, banter back and forth for a while, and then explore and uncover the secrets of the island, as well as uncover the secrets that lay beyond the island.

To be honest, I didn't know what I would expect from this game and throughout the game I was surprised by quite a lot of things. I experienced a lot of feelings of discomfort, tension, and the sense of unsettlement... and at times was creeped out and overwhelmed by how intensely I felt these feelings. I was also surprised at the fact the game explores the issue of the damage that false accusations can cause. At one point, I didnt know if I would be able to keep playing because of the feelings I felt. This, to me, is a lot better than the other genres of horror games, to me this is REAL horror.

Thrown into a monochromatic-like world and seemingly stranded on a deserted island, you get introduced a young girl named Hailey and the voice in her head, a 33yo man seeking both knowledge and revenge. The Music Machine is not a game for everyone. Game is quite short but really up to the player how much time they spend exploring. A full playthrough could be done in around an hour but personally I loaded the game straight back up after finishing and found several areas I had missed which expanded upon my first run and tied up some loose ends. Will not go into the details as that would spoil all the fun. If you are familiar with the developers previous work 'The Moon Sliver' you should know what to expect, stark imagery, atmospheric soundtrack and slowly unravelling plotline. With that said it is more directed with less reading involved and far better visuals imo.

Would like to mention it's not a horror game with jump scares, nonstop action or much that would probably shock you but it is somewhat thought provoking and you can tell it's a Iabour of love. Well, this is the third game by the developer of Fingerbone and The Moon Sliver, definitely set in the same world as the latter based on the religious scripts found in game regarding the worlds mythos. This was by far the best effort yet. The story itself was engaging and had two obvious layers (the possessed girl and the worlds mythos itself) with a lot of subtext regarding forgiveness and redemption.

The world was beautiful. Stunning even. Talk about maximizing the effect through minimalism! The colors and the images were truly evocative.

The gameplay was similar to the prior two games in that you move around using the mouse and WASD, and interact via mouseclicks, but with the added feature of actually being able to use a couple items within the scope of the game.

The story was stellar IMO. Again, a minimalist approach thhat really spurs the imagination.

All told, I think it took me about two actual hours to complete the game, including going back to check out the Easter Egg that was presented in the end game credits, which was very nice.

reviewText:
If you don't cringe at the thought of a game based solely on exploration, then you could safely quit reading this review and go buy The Music Machine now. This narrative psychological horror adventure is easily one of the better examples of the genre.

It is very difficult to explain how eerie and yet strikingly beautiful the monochromatic artstyle is, because neither the videos nor the screenshots do it justice. Simply walking within this world is a fascinating experience worth the tiny pricetag. Accompanied by a brilliant soundtrack and a minimalistic sound design that highlight the atmosphere, you will for once actually not mind wandering aimlessly around and staring fascinated at the shadows of the trees and the patterns on the walls.

And yes, you will occasionally wander aimlessly around not knowing what to do next, so some patience and some observation skills are required. Thankfully this is one of the few walking exploration games that is mostly accessible, even if you aren't a great fan of the genre. Despite my best efforts to become confused on where I was and how to proceed, I was most of the time pleasantly surprised when I accidentally stumbled onto what turned out to be the obvious next step.

I am very unwilling to divulge anything about the story, because I was glad to have read very little about it before playing. The game introduces its characters through small snippets of dialogue that pack a few shocking punches yet are often quite entertaining in their oddness. I especially appreciated how beautifully tight the dialogues were despite (and sometimes because of) their occasional melodramatic crescendos. Suffice to say that, if you don't enjoy playing games that are trying their best to make you profoundly uncomfortable, this may not be the game for you. The Music Machine revels in the existential perversity of its world and the troubling dysfunctional relationship of its (surprisingly well realised) protagonists. It is ultimately a story of two broken people that are almost too engrossed in their personal dramas to be actually shocked by the horror of a world crafted by perverted supernatural entities. And despite its occasional flaws (that include some pacing issues and also some glaring typos that are hard to excuse in narratively driven games), I was very intrigued by the well-rounded and well-explored story, enough to try and uncover both endings.

All in all a very interesting game, unique, memorable, intriguingly written and visually stunning. If you're at all curious, don't hesitate.

reviewText:
This is a revised review, based on some comments from the game’s developer.

Short version: 71%When you mix together a great two-character drama based entirely on dialogues, a bunch of rather empty walking simulation levels, and a visual style that murders your retina… you get The Music Machine.

Long version:The Music Machine is a walking simulator exploration game with a hint of Silent Hill style suspension horror and a great dose of character drama between the two protagonists: Haley, a 13-year old girl, and Quintin, the ghost of a middle-aged bachelor who now controls her body on the intent of killing her. To do so, they travel to a derelict island, where they find a strange temple organ which teleports them to a few desolate alien worlds.

Their banter is the high point of the game. It not only manages to tell their backstory without resorting to long plot dumps, but it is also a good tool to keep up the suspension. Unlike the supposed plot about the heavenly world builders; it feels like their story is cryptic only to mask that it makes no sense.

For a game, The Music Machine is… not pleasant. The starting island is hard to navigate and you may miss half of the dialogues by accidentally stumbling up on the way forward. The alien worlds are thankfully short, but they are empty. And finally, the visual style may look especially great on storefront images, but actually seeing this two-colour high-contrast style in motion will physically hurt your eyes.

If you're a fan of The Vanishing of Ethan Carter and other exploration games, The Music Machine is well worth your time.

reviewText:
I've been a bit of a fan of David Szymanski's games. I stuck The Moon Sliver in our indie games of the year list, while the story wasn't the most original, and it didn't look the best, the way it told its story was fascinating. Fingerbones was rough, but its story unique and oblique, just about as dark as anything else in gaming. The Music Machine mixes cues from both games, it's dreamy, vague, and eventually, unremittingly bleak

Like the two previous games, The Music Machine is a narrative exploration game, a 'walking simulator' if you will. You play as a young girl, possessed by a vengeful spirit, who puppets her around with the ultimate aim of killing her in the worst way possible. The game commendably pitches this against a light hearted tone, the girl is playful, the relationship between the two is more familial than murderous. It helps soften the characters, making them likable and relatable, something that can be undermined to brilliant effect later on.

This is true of the world too. Szymanski's games have never been lookers, but with The Music Machine he's used two tone colours, setting black against colour, to create a striking and at times beautiful world. The large swathes of abyss black create doubt, in a world so threateningly desolate they could be hiding anything. The structures become peering obelisks, the simplicity of the world unsettling, it's something that's grounded in the narrative, and if it's a deliberate attempt to draw from limitations, it works brilliantly.

It's fair to say that The Music Machine is an original story. There's a moment, or a representation of a character, that I'm less sure lands, it's unique certainly, but in what is otherwise quite a heavy game, and a heavy moment, it just falls on the comical side of absurd. Not that comedy has no place in the game, The Music Machine has its fair share of humour, usually as part of a very well written script. As mentioned the relationship between Hayley and Quintin is superb, they bring the barren world to life, it's a very natural relationship, despite its origins. It's also a parallel for the structure of the game. The light-heartedness, the sense of wonder, eventually becomes undermined, you suddenly realise that the impish threat that had seemed no more than a curiosity has begun to loom over you. Each new area carries with it the threat of the unknown, but there was a point where the game had become genuinely unsettling. That said, one of the possible endings is a little fluffed, I got it out of curiosity rather than malevolence, meaning it lost a lot of its intended impact.

The Music Machine takes a very grounded issue, the damage of a false accusation, and then throws it in to a surreal high concept world. It's a unique story, the reveal of the what and why of the music machine itself is an old-fashioned kind of horror, and depending on your choices it can explore the darker side of humanity, resentment, and revenge. As usual for anything from this genre it’s not for everyone, it’s not jump scares and gore, but it’s a fantastic story. unique and quietly unsettling

reviewText:
I thoroughly enjoyed this game. As many others have said, the art and music/sound effects are superb; combined with the underlying premise and developing story, they create a frightening environment. Even during a second playthrough (not long after the first), I still found the hairs on my arms rising at times.

In the interests of frank disclosure, there are a couple of rough edges:

-Occasional spelling/grammer errors (impacts immersion)
-A clunky checkpoint-based save system. This is apparently part of the Unity platform on which the game is based. The developer is aware of its limitations, and is considering improvements in his next game.
-A somewhat confusing inventory system. There are many items with which you can interact, but most of these interactions are inconsequential. What you are listening for is a 3-tone sound, which means you have picked up an item that is critical to the progression of the story.

There are other areas for improvement. For example, some people are of course bothered by no achievements, and the fact that the game can be completed in 1-2 hours. But those things actually don't phase me at all. And despite my list of areas for improvement, I have absolutely no hesitation in recommending this game. Seriously, just buy it, even if for no other reason than the experience of moving through such a trippy environment. It's well worth it!

reviewText: The Music Machine involves the story of a 13-year-old girl on an island who has had her body controlled for three months by a spirit who we learn has nefarious intentions (and why.) This tale takes place in the same universe as Moon Sliver, but is longer, has a more fleshed-out story and game mechanics, and enjoys a more signature graphic styling, forgoing Half-Life 2 and Arma-style graphics in favor of one color-tone, cell-shaded graphics that I can only even vaguely match to Killer 7. This game has more control, style, and tone than the predecessor, and the story really drew me in. For the price, you can't get a better deal.

The Music Machine is the companion piece to The Moon Sliver, and delivers just as highly. The Music Machine has beautifully rendered monochromatic backgrounds which, as usual for David's games, a wonderful and evocative atmosphere of strangeness and uncertainty. The music, effects, writing, and characters bring this story to life and, while relatively short (right around an hour), is a game that players can revisit and experience again. This is one of the most fascinating and philisophical of David's designs, with many very real world questions being raised. The slow reveal of the story works wonderfully for this type of horror game and I sincerely hope that David continues to create these types narrative based games, horror or not. The Music Machine is a work of art, and highly recommended.\n\n*I've played each of David's designs, and highly recommend them for those who are seeking an experience that is more than just a game, but an exploration of horror narrative, and how a game can be more than just an entertainment piece. Each of David's games are a work of art.

Games like The Music Machine don't come around very often.  When they do, it seems that even many of the people who would enjoy them feel reluctant to give them a try. Sometimes a game looks a little too strange and people (at least, people like me) get anxious about the idea of wasting their money. In the hopes of addressing some of the fence-sitters, let me simply say that The Music Machine is the best horror game I played in all of 2015.

When The Music Machine begins, all you know is that you're a spirit controlling the body of a young girl. To say more could constitute major spoilers, but even from this fairly unique premise, the story takes some unexpected turns. Speaking of story, the plot of The Music Machine is tenuously connected to the plot of The Moon Sliver, David Szymanski's previous game, but The Music Machine is not a sequel and either game can be enjoyed without having played the other.
Depending on how often you stop to take in the view, accompanied by a genuinely excellent score, you'll likely spend two or three hours exploring the various monochromatic areas of the abandoned island, and it is in this exploration that The Music Machine shines. Almost every object can be examined and doing so will usually trigger a short conversation between the two main characters. The dialogue is superbly written and you can even keep walking around once a conversation has been initiated, unbound by the object you were examining.

When a game is this short, a discussion of its length is unavoidable, which is why I feel I need to mention that the length of The Music Machine is absolutely perfect.
When a game can be completed in a single sitting, it's story stays fresh in your mind throughout it's runtime. Arbitrarily padding a game like this to extend it's length would only lessen the experience in the long run. Keeping a story succinct means it never gets dull.

If you don't like slow pace, this isn't probably something you'd go for. Plot is bizarre, art style is unique, and atmosphere is killer. I don't recommend playing in incriments as the plot is more dialogue-driven and you can forget what was said the last time you played. I almost wish there was voice, but actual audio might just ruin the atmosphere itself.

I've written two sections. The second section is aimed specifically at those who have played The Moon Sliver. So potential spoilers when you get to the part.

Although it's described by players and the developer alike as a horror game, I personally don't agree. (Though obviously, genre specification is inherently a subjective thing.)

It's an exploratory, narrative-driven game. I wouldn't call it as scary as much as it's surreal, and at most, unsettling.
You're in a strange environment (in part due to the dichromatic visual style), and as you explore and proceed, the world becomes increasingly stranger. The story follows the same pattern. It starts off weird (you play as a ghost who's puppeting the body of a young girl, and looking to kill her), yet ultimately moves into even more fantastical directions that's much more vast in scope than I had expected from the start.

I enjoyed the tale immensely. Much of the tale is conveyed through the internal dialogue between the two characters (the girl and the ghost who's controlling her) and they are a rather interesting duo imo. It's a short game (1 hr average I think for a full playthrough) but the way the dialogue develops feels both natural and informative, allowing the player to learn more about them while figuring out the craziness that's happening in the game.

The pacing of the game and story is as good as the character development. The second 'half' feels like it snowballs a bit too quickly, especially near the end, but I think that's inevitable given the number of...environments that the game has. Not saying it was not enjoyable nor satisfying, and that it seemed rushed, or that the dev should have fleshed out the latter half. The pacing just caught me off guard is all.

And besides, the final sequence IS good: the one area of the game that I would call horror, and it's very effective. It's an excellent wrap up for the story, the characters, and the game as a whole (followed by a great epilogue-y sequence that I won't spoil).

So overall, I did very much like the game. The story and characters were both engaging, and the environments were all creepily alien and oh-so intriguing. I felt for their characters during my brief time with them. I felt dread whether I was exploring small claustrophobic corridors or vast, desolate fields.

Again, I treat it as narrative-driven, exploratory game. So there are only a few puzzles, and they're all very simple. But I liked that; they didn't bog down the experience of the narrative.
And relately, one small detail that I liked was the ability to pick up most miscellaneous objects. Without spoiling much, this interface IS useful for some of the 'puzzles', but what I liked was that for the most part it, such movement was useless. I know it sounds silly but that was part of the reason why I liked Amnesia: The Dark Descent. It just felt more immersive, and as enjoyable to me as the random descriptions you get when examining random objects. It adds just the right amount of interactivity to augment the player's engagement with this world.

There were even times where I was pointlessly doing X trying to figure out obstacle Y...but it didn't bother me. It felt organic; my trying to find my way through the game.

Now for those who have played The Moon Sliver. I'm sure you're wondering about its relationship to the game.

Rest assured, even though TMM functions well as a standalone game imo, it manages to, in the process, expand, clarify, and enriches the backstory of TMS. And it's very satisfying. There is one particular detail in TMS that I was disappointed was never explaineds/shown explicitly. And it's there, right smack near the end of TMM. But if you never played TMS, it wouldn't be as poignant, but it would still be relevant, and would not stick out.

Gameplaywise, it's much more of a game than TMS, and I think it's a good thing. It does so without sacrificing narrative quality. E.g. Having an inventory screen did not detract from the experience.

The way the story is conveyed is different, but I think both games are interesting in their own right, and they both kind of stem directly from the games' unique settings (conversations with a ghost versus a person looking back and reminiscing).

I think pacing is better in TMS, but I'm 90% sure that's just due to the order I happened to explore things in TMS.
As I stated in the first section of this review, there's more interaction in TMM, and that's good for it as a game. If you liked TMS, there's a high chance you'll like TMM, as a whole, if not just for the tie-ins alone.

Games like The Music Machine don't come around very often.  When they do, it seems that even many of the people who would enjoy them feel reluctant to give them a try. Sometimes a game looks a little too strange and people (at least, people like me) get anxious about the idea of wasting their money. In the hopes of addressing some of the fence-sitters, let me simply say that The Music Machine is the best horror game I played in all of 2015.

When The Music Machine begins, all you know is that you're a spirit controlling the body of a young girl. To say more could constitute major spoilers, but even from this fairly unique premise, the story takes some unexpected turns. Speaking of story, the plot of The Music Machine is tenuously connected to the plot of The Moon Sliver, David Szymanski's previous game, but The Music Machine is not a sequel and either game can be enjoyed without having played the other.
Depending on how often you stop to take in the view, accompanied by a genuinely excellent score, you'll likely spend two or three hours exploring the various monochromatic areas of the abandoned island, and it is in this exploration that The Music Machine shines. Almost every object can be examined and doing so will usually trigger a short conversation between the two main characters. The dialogue is superbly written and you can even keep walking around once a conversation has been initiated, unbound by the object you were examining.

When a game is this short, a discussion of its length is unavoidable, which is why I feel I need to mention that the length of The Music Machine is absolutely perfect.
When a game can be completed in a single sitting, it's story stays fresh in your mind throughout it's runtime. Arbitrarily padding a game like this to extend it's length would only lessen the experience in the long run. Keeping a story succinct means it never gets dull.
